p: Strongyloidiasis causes diarrhea and malnutrition in SSA, although there is little information on its distribution or disease burden ( Table 4), in part because of the difficulties in diagnosing this infection. In one study, strongyloidiasis accounted for 5.3% of diarrhea in malnourished Nigerian children [65]. Two other intestinal nematode infections are focally endemic. Oesophagostomum bifurcum is common in northern Ghana and Togo [66], and Ternidens deminutus (the “false hookworm”) occurs in Zimbabwe [67].
